<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Findustries%2Ftechnology%20media%20and%20telecommunications%2Ftelecommunications%2Four%20insights%2Fresponsible%20ai%20a%20business%20imperative%20for%20telcos%2Fresponsible-ai-a-business-imperative-for-telcos.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="responsible-ai-a-business-imperative-for-telcos" data-layer-report-name="responsible-ai-a-business-imperative-for-telcos>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (9 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong>Over the past decade,</strong> the telecom industry has faced one daunting challenge after another. Telcos have endured relentless competitive pressure from fast-moving technology companies that entered their core sectors of communications, connectivity, and data transport. In the hopes of igniting revenue growth, telcos have sought to <a href="/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/our-insights/a-blueprint-for-telecoms-critical-reinvention">reinvent themselves</a>. They have created new tech-driven product offeringsfrom the Internet of Things (IoT) and software as a service (SaaS) to over-the-top (OTT) video streaming. They have also ventured into adjacent industries such as insurance, financial services, and healthcare to offer new B2C and B2B services. Some of those initiatives have been moderately successful. But the truth is that telcos still struggle to compete with nimbler and more highly capitalized tech companies.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>About the authors</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>This article is a collaborative effort by <a href="/our-people/andrea-travasoni">Andrea Travasoni</a>, <a href="/our-people/benjamim-vieira">Benjamim Vieira</a>, <a href="/our-people/ferry-grijpink">Ferry Grijpink</a>, and <a href="/our-people/roger-roberts">Roger Roberts</a>, with Ccile Prinsen and Vctor Trigo, representing views from McKinseys Technology, Media & Telecommunications Practice.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>AI gives telcos another chance to reinvent themselves. The goal is to become <a href="/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/our-insights/the-ai-native-telco-radical-transformation-to-thrive-in-turbulent-times">AI-native organizations</a> that embed AI into every aspect of the business to help drive growth and renewal. If telcos act quickly, they can lead the way in deploying both <a href="/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/our-insights/how-generative-ai-could-revitalize-profitability-for-telcos">generative AI</a> (gen AI) to improve the customer experience and cut costs and analytical AI to optimize their back-end operations and infrastructure. Many telcos have already begun to implement gen AI, deriving significant cost savings in areas such as marketing, sales, and customer service. McKinsey research shows that gen AI could drive significant EBITDA gains for telcos, with returns on incremental margins increasing three to four percentage points in two years, and as much as eight to ten percentage points in five years.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c79615a9-989c-49d4-a9f1-29b69c827337"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c79615a9-989c-49d4-a9f1-29b69c827337" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><a href="/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/our-insights/how-generative-ai-could-revitalize-profitability-for-telcos">How generative AI could revitalize profitability for telcos</a>, McKinsey, February 21, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<!-- -->
<p>However, telcos cannot transform themselves into AI-native companies without also focusing acutely on <a href="/capabilities/quantumblack/how-we-help-clients/generative-ai/responsible-ai-principles">responsible AI</a> (RAI), which is the practice of deploying AI in ways that are ethical, safe, transparent, and compliant with regulations. In the highly regulated telecom industry, RAI frameworks that govern accountability and transparency are critical to gaining consumer trust, protecting sensitive data, and safeguarding against security threats. All this makes RAI more than just an ethical exercise for telcos. It is also a business imperative.</p>
<p>To showcase the importance of RAI, we conducted an analysis of 100 critical AI use cases that telcos could develop. For each use case, we indicated the optimal level of RAI maturity, considering the inherent risks. For example, an advanced level of RAI would reinforce a use case that manages customers personal information. Our analysis indicates that telcos implementing the most advanced RAI practices could deploy use cases that collectively capture up to $250 billion in value worldwide by 2040, 44 percent of the full industry-wide value created by AI during that period (exhibit).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="08f5b046-3e53-43c8-bce9-07de28e7408f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="08f5b046-3e53-43c8-bce9-07de28e7408f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><a href="/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/our-insights/how-generative-ai-could-revitalize-profitability-for-telcos">How generative AI could revitalize profitability for telcos</a>, McKinsey, February 21, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit </span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/telecommunications/our%20insights/responsible%20ai%20a%20business%20imperative%20for%20telcos/resiliency-ai-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="By 2040, telcos that use advanced responsible AI practices could capture up to $250 billion in value worldwide." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/telecommunications/our%20insights/responsible%20ai%20a%20business%20imperative%20for%20telcos/resiliency-ai-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>How exactly can RAI create value? For starters, just like all AI deployments, RAI can significantly improve business processes and streamline technology integrations to reduce costs. Effective RAI can also strengthen brand reputation, with higher customer acquisition and retention often propelling revenue growth. In addition, RAI can help reduce commercial and reputational risks across an organizations full suite of AI tools and applications, ensuring that they perform at the highest levels of accuracy. For example, RAI practices could help ensure a companys customer service chatbot doesnt use biased, incorrect, or sensitive language and that it never recommends a competitors product or service.</p>
<p>In this article, we outline how telcos can design and implement an RAI framework that could generate significant bottom-line impact. A strong RAI framework includes maturity models that telcos can use to assess their current strengths and weaknesses, as well as best practices to move through foundational, evolving, emerging, and advanced stages of RAI implementation. As they deploy such a framework, telcos will clarify their individual RAI road maps, including how to structure and implement governance, technology, and operating models. RAI frameworks can ensure that a telcos AI deployments remain aligned with revenue and business goals.</p>
<h2>Industry-standard RAI frameworks are rare</h2>
<p>Telcos can benefit from RAI in multiple ways: better business outcomes, competitive advantage, sustainable growth, increased customer trust, enhanced operational efficiency, stronger talent attraction, and, of course, financial gains. Forward-thinking telcos recognize that robust RAI governance serves as a set of good brakes that enable them to drive faster to harness the full potential of AI while mitigating risks.</p>
<p>Based on our interviews with senior leaders at telcos worldwide, few are currently at the advanced stage of RAI deployment, with a majority still at the foundational or evolving stages. One of the biggest roadblocks to telcos deploying RAI is the lack of industry standards. Telcos want to deploy RAI, but there is no single agreed-upon framework to aid them in their journeys. Thus, instead of proactively adopting RAI, telcos are reactionary, adding piecemeal governance standards as new regulatory requirements emerge. This approach helps telcos avoid legal and financial repercussions but does not result in the type of cohesive and strategic RAI deployments necessary to fuel innovation.</p>
<p>Many governments have proposed or passed legislation to ensure that AI deployments are fair, transparent, accountable, and secure (Table 1). International organizations have proposed global policies for RAI, but none of these policies have been adopted on a wide scale (Table 2). And none of these regulations or policies are specific to the telecom industry.</p>

<p>While telecom industry associations are making progress on defining RAI standards, there are still barriers to achieving near-term success:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Limited leadership from central organizations.</em> Telecom industry associations and standard-setting bodies can show more leadership in advancing RAI practices. While some organizations actively promote RAI, few have developed comprehensive frameworks or provided clear guidance to their members. This gap hinders telcos from adopting best practices and achieving consistent standards of AI responsibility.</li>
    <li><em>Limited availability of RAI industry benchmarks.</em> The absence of RAI benchmarks in the telecom industry creates a significant challenge for telcos. Benchmarks serve as reference points that allow companies to evaluate their performance relative to industry standards and identify areas for improvement. Without these benchmarks, telcos lack metrics to gauge their progress in implementing RAI. This gap complicates efforts to foster transparency, as key stakeholdersincluding regulators, consumers, and partnershave no clear standards against which to measure a telcos AI initiatives.</li>
</ul>
<h2>RAI frameworks for telcos have four characteristics</h2>
<p>Despite a lack of clear standards for their industry, telcos have a strong desire to implement RAI. In our interviews , the majority of leaders expressed interest in creating and deploying RAI frameworks tailored not just to the telecom industry but to their individual businesses. Most hoped to begin their RAI journey with maturity models that assess where they stand and define the specific steps needed to become advanced users of RAI. Telcos see maturity models as a level-setting exercise to inform their strategic plans. They want to deploy easy-to-use modeling tools to score their levels of RAI readiness and translate these findings into executive-level summaries with calls to action. Unfortunately, few of the leaders we interviewed said they currently use RAI maturity models, mostly because of the tools limited availability. Telecom industry groups are working to define RAI maturity models specific to telcos, but it is still early days. For example, the Global System for Mobile Communications Association (GSMA) only recently created a tool for telcos to measure their RAI maturity.</p>
<p>What specific characteristics should an RAI framework for telcos include? Based on our interviews, a strong RAI framework for the telecom industry might encompass four key characteristics:</p>
<ol>
    <li><em>Industry-specific maturity models.</em> These tools help telcos assess their RAI readiness and define specific benchmarks for each level. The models consider telcos unique goals and challenges with AI in light of a highly competitive market, interconnected networks, and extensive exposure to consumer data.</li>
    <li><em>Clear RAI guidelines.</em> These building blocks offer a comprehensive overview of the various elements that comprise an RAI strategy, including governance, risk management, data quality, and ethical guidelines.</li>
    <li><em>Best practices.</em> These practical strategies show telcos how to implement RAI effectively, including proven practices that advanced telcos have already successfully adopted and measured.</li>
    <li><em>Progress metrics.</em> These measurement guidelines outline practical steps telcos can follow to improve their RAI capabilities and progress through each stage of maturity: foundational, evolving, performing, and advanced.</li>
</ol>
<h3>Industry-specific maturity models for assessment and goal setting</h3>
<p>An effective RAI framework should include an easy-to-use maturity-modeling tool to help telcos fully understand their baseline AI readiness and identify opportunities for growth and improvement. Maturity models help telcos capture their full AI potential at every stage of deployment.</p>
<p>Operators just starting on their RAI journey can use maturity models to establish and measure essential foundational requirements. These include adopting core RAI principles, defining key roles and responsibilities, and setting up initial governance structures. Foundational requirements also include establishing a code of ethics for AI, appointing a chief AI officer, and creating an AI governance board. Companies in this foundational stage of RAI adoption are mostly looking to enhance specific aspects of their operations, such as improving operational efficiency or automating routine tasks like customer service.</p>
<p>On the other end of the spectrum are companies in the advanced stage of RAI deployment. These telcos use AI to create high-impact, customer-facing use cases and integrate AI deeply into their strategic decision-making processes. Examples include using AI to create personalized customer experiences, to analyze vast amounts of data for strategic insights, or to spur innovation in product development. Thus, maturity models should integrate benchmarks and best practices for advanced users, including sophisticated risk management frameworks, comprehensive governance models, and continuous monitoring and improvement processes. For companies at the advanced stage, maturity models may also include AI auditing processes to ensure transparency and accountability.</p>
<h3>Clear RAI guidelines to define overall strategy</h3>
<p>An effective RAI framework outlines every step of a telcos AI strategy and long-term road map. It includes definitions for governance, risk management, data quality, and ethics, with strategic and operational best practices to advance these policies at each stage of RAI maturity. The following are the essential components of an RAI framework.</p>
<p><strong><em>Strategy.</em></strong> This defines the vision and principles for RAI governance in alignment with the organizations values and strategic goals. Here is what a robust strategy should include:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Vision.</em> A clear articulation of what RAI means for the organization and how it aligns with the companys broader mission</li>
    <li><em>Principles.</em> Foundational ethical guidelines that steer AI development and deployment, ensuring fairness, transparency, accountability, and inclusivity</li>
    <li><em>Alignment.</em> Guidelines to ensure that the RAI strategy is consistent with the organizations strategic objectives</li>
    <li><em>Regulations.</em> Rules to ensure adherence to local and international standards to mitigate compliance risks</li>
</ul>
<p><strong><em>Enablers.</em></strong> These activate well-defined best practices that are integral to a comprehensive RAI road map. Key features include the following:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Tools.</em> An inventory of the responsible AI tools the organization will use for model validation, bias detection, and interpretability to ensure ethical AI development</li>
    <li><em>Training.</em> A plan for continuous education and training to help employees understand AIs ethical implications and technical aspects</li>
    <li><em>Change management.</em> A structured approach the organization will use to transition individuals, teams, and organizations toward RAI practices</li>
    <li><em>Communication.</em> Clear, cascading communication channels to ensure that everyone in the organization is aligned with the RAI strategy and principles</li>
</ul>
<p><strong><em>Operating model.</em></strong> This helps ensure that the right talent, governance structures, team composition, and processes are in place to allow companies to implement RAI across all business activities. Critical elements include the following:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Talent.</em> The recruitment and development of professionals with the necessary skills in AI, ethics, and governance</li>
    <li><em>Governance.</em> Robust governance structures that define roles, responsibilities, and decision-making processes related to RAI</li>
    <li><em>Team structure.</em> Formation of cross-functional teams that include data scientists, ethicists, legal experts, and business leaders</li>
    <li><em>Processes.</em> Implementation of standardized RAI development, deployment, and monitoring procedures to ensure consistency and accountability</li>
    <li><em>Culture.</em> The creation of a culture of ethical awareness and responsibility regarding AI, which encourages employees to speak up about potential issues</li>
</ul>
<p><strong><em>Risk.</em></strong> This emphasizes the importance of proactively monitoring and mitigating risks associated with AI and involves the following:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Measurement.</em> Development of metrics and KPIs to evaluate the performance and risks of AI systems</li>
    <li><em>Monitoring.</em> Continuous observation of AI models for signs of bias, errors, or other issues through techniques such as risk management and third-party solution auditing</li>
    <li><em>Reviews.</em> Implementation of rigorous review-and-challenge processes such as red teaming (simulating attacks to identify vulnerabilities) and war gaming (stress testing models under hypothetical scenarios)</li>
    <li><em>Reporting.</em> Regular documentation and communication to stakeholders to ensure transparency and to facilitate informed AI decision making</li>
</ul>
<h2>Best practices to deploy RAI in the telecom sector</h2>
<p>An RAI framework for the telecom industry should provide specific best practices for each of the four key components described above. These best practices can help telcos apply general principles of RAI in a manner that acknowledges the industrys unique challenges and opportunities, such as using AI for network optimization or customer churn prediction. A comprehensive RAI framework provides best practices for each maturity levelfoundational, evolving, performing, and advancedcreating a road map that helps telcos advance from one level to the next.</p>
<p>What follows are sample best practices telcos could adopt at the foundational level of RAI deployment, though a full framework would provide a greater number of best practices and tailor them more specifically to an individual telcos situation:</p>
<ul>
    <li>Strategy:
    <ul>
        <li><em>Vision.</em> Write a high-level statement articulating the organizations commitment to RAI that is aligned with the broader mission and serves as a guiding light for all AI activities.</li>
        <li><em>Principles.</em> Define early ethical principles that provide a clear framework for RAI, touching on fairness, transparency, accountability, and inclusivity.</li>
        <li><em>Alignment.</em> Develop a road map to incorporate AI principles into the organizations overall business goals.</li>
        <li><em>Regulations.</em> Conduct initial research to understand the regulatory requirements at both the national and international levels.</li>
    </ul>
    </li>
    <li>Enablers:
    <ul>
        <li><em>Tools.</em> Find and adopt a first set of RAI tools to help with model validation, bias detection, and interpretability.</li>
        <li><em>Training.</em> Conduct an initial training program to educate employees about AIs ethical implications to build awareness of RAI practices across the organization.</li>
        <li><em>Change management.</em> Start basic processes to help the organization adapt to RAI, such as creating a simple road map to describe the transition process.</li>
        <li><em>Communication.</em> Choose channelsfor example, a newsletter, blog, website, or social media platformto disseminate information to employees and external stakeholders about the companys RAI principles.</li>
    </ul>
    </li>
    <li>Operating model:
    <ul>
        <li><em>Talent.</em> Create a plan to obtain the necessary talent to deploy RAI, including required new hires and plans for upskilling existing employees.</li>
        <li><em>Governance.</em> Set up an initial governance structure that defines roles and responsibilities for key stakeholders and outlines basic procedures.</li>
        <li><em>Team structure.</em> Take a high-level inventory of existing employeesincluding data scientists, developers, IT staff, legal experts, product managers, and business leaderswho could potentially join a cross-functional team to support RAI initiatives.</li>
        <li><em>Processes.</em> Research standardized procedures for AI development, deployment, and monitoring, and introduce an initial set of unified procedures.</li>
        <li><em>Culture.</em> Create an initial internal communications campaign to introduce the concept of RAI.</li>
    </ul>
    </li>
    <li>Risk:
    <ul>
        <li><em>Measurement.</em> Develop basic metrics and KPIs to evaluate the performance of early RAI systems and set up initial measurement frameworks.</li>
        <li><em>Monitoring.</em> Establish basic processes to continually observe AI models to detect signs of bias, errors, or other issues.</li>
        <li><em>Review.</em> Create initial review-and-challenge processes, including plans for red teaming and war gaming.</li>
        <li><em>Reporting.</em> Set up reporting mechanisms to document and communicate RAI findings, including basic reports to keep stakeholders informed about the state of AI initiatives.</li>
    </ul>
    </li>
</ul>
<h2>Progress metrics to evolve from a foundational to an advanced maturity level</h2>
<p>An effective RAI framework should offer a structured pathway for telcos to improve their RAI maturity over time. At each maturity level, the framework should include specific progress metrics a telco needs to meet to advance to the next level.</p>
<p>For example, at the foundational level, one progress metric might be: Share the companys RAI vision with all employees through an internal communications campaign and test their knowledge of the program through a feedback mechanism. At the evolving method, a metric might be: Finish a multipart risk training program for the RAI cross-functional team. And at the performing level, a metric might be: Develop and launch an RAI innovation lab to foster continuous improvement and experimentation.</p>
<p>Each telco will have different goals for RAI deployment, so their progress metrics will differ based on the unique objectives defined in their initial road maps.</p>
<hr>
<p>Telcos with structured RAI practices are not just leaders from an ethical standpoint; they also stand to generate billions of dollars in additional value. Investing in RAI may position todays beleaguered telcos for a competitive edge in the next decade, providing a new avenue for them to compete alongside technology companies. By prioritizing RAI, telecom operators can capture the full potential of AI for their businesses and build trust with customers, leading to new innovations and new revenues. Emphasizing RAI can also help telecom companies attract and retain the best talent, fostering a culture of continuous improvement. Put simply, implementing AI responsibly makes good business sense.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong><a href="/our-people/andrea-travasoni">Andrea Travasoni</a></strong> is a senior partner in McKinseys Milan office; <strong><a href="/our-people/benjamim-vieira">Benjamim Vieira</a></strong> is a senior partner in the Madrid office, where <strong>Vctor Trigo</strong> is an associate partner; <strong><a href="/our-people/ferry-grijpink">Ferry Grijpink</a></strong> is a partner in the Amsterdam office; <strong><a href="/our-people/roger-roberts">Roger Roberts</a></strong> is a partner in the Bay Area office; and <strong>Ccile Prinsen</strong> is an associate partner in the London office.</p>
<hr>
<p>This article was edited by Kristi Essick, an executive editor in the Bay Area office.</p></div></div></div></section><section class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 mck-u-screen-only"><div type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"Responsible AI A business imperative for telcos","displayName":"Responsible AI A business imperative for telcos","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"11030ecc-7d8a-41dd-a699-9359fec05c35","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Responsible AI: A business imperative for telcos"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":""},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Telcos that use responsible AI frameworks can unlock new revenue streams and spur long-awaited growth."}},"sEODescription":{"value":""},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2024-10-18T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[Audio 1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eOver the past decade,\u003c/strong\u003e the telecom industry has faced one daunting challenge after another. Telcos have endured relentless competitive pressure from fast-moving technology companies that entered their core sectors of communications, connectivity, and data transport. In the hopes of igniting revenue growth, telcos have sought to \u003ca href=\"/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/our-insights/a-blueprint-for-telecoms-critical-reinvention\"\u003ereinvent themselves\u003c/a\u003e. They have created new tech-driven product offerings\u0026mdash;from the Internet of Things (IoT) and software as a service (SaaS) to over-the-top (OTT) video streaming. They have also ventured into adjacent industries such as insurance, financial services, and healthcare to offer new B2C and B2B services. Some of those initiatives have been moderately successful. But the truth is that telcos still struggle to compete with nimbler and more highly capitalized tech companies.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar authors]]\n\u003cp\u003eAI gives telcos another chance to reinvent themselves. The goal is to become \u003ca href=\"/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/our-insights/the-ai-native-telco-radical-transformation-to-thrive-in-turbulent-times\"\u003eAI-native organizations\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that embed AI into every aspect of the business to help drive growth and renewal. If telcos act quickly, they can lead the way in deploying both \u003ca href=\"/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/our-insights/how-generative-ai-could-revitalize-profitability-for-telcos\"\u003egenerative AI\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;(gen AI) to improve the customer experience and cut costs and analytical AI to optimize their back-end operations and infrastructure. Many telcos have already begun to implement gen AI, deriving significant cost savings in areas such as marketing, sales, and customer service. McKinsey research shows that gen AI could drive significant EBITDA gains for telcos, with returns on incremental margins increasing three to four percentage points in two years, and as much as eight to ten percentage points in five years.[[footnote 1]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, telcos cannot transform themselves into AI-native companies without also focusing acutely on \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/quantumblack/how-we-help-clients/generative-ai/responsible-ai-principles\"\u003eresponsible AI\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;(RAI), which is the practice of deploying AI in ways that are ethical, safe, transparent, and compliant with regulations. In the highly regulated telecom industry, RAI frameworks that govern accountability and transparency are critical to gaining consumer trust, protecting sensitive data, and safeguarding against security threats. All this makes RAI more than just an ethical exercise for telcos. It is also a business imperative.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo showcase the importance of RAI, we conducted an analysis of 100 critical AI use cases that telcos could develop. For each use case, we indicated the optimal level of RAI maturity, considering the inherent risks. For example, an advanced level of RAI would reinforce a use case that manages customers\u0026rsquo; personal information. Our analysis indicates that telcos implementing the most advanced RAI practices could deploy use cases that collectively capture up to $250 billion in value worldwide by 2040, 44 percent of the full industry-wide value created by AI during that period (exhibit).[[footnote 2]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eHow exactly can RAI create value? For starters, just like all AI deployments, RAI can significantly improve business processes and streamline technology integrations to reduce costs. Effective RAI can also strengthen brand reputation, with higher customer acquisition and retention often propelling revenue growth. In addition, RAI can help reduce commercial and reputational risks across an organization\u0026rsquo;s full suite of AI tools and applications, ensuring that they perform at the highest levels of accuracy. For example, RAI practices could help ensure a company\u0026rsquo;s customer service chatbot doesn\u0026rsquo;t use biased, incorrect, or sensitive language and that it never recommends a competitor\u0026rsquo;s product or service.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn this article, we outline how telcos can design and implement an RAI framework that could generate significant bottom-line impact. A strong RAI framework includes maturity models that telcos can use to assess their current strengths and weaknesses, as well as best practices to move through foundational, evolving, emerging, and advanced stages of RAI implementation. As they deploy such a framework, telcos will clarify their individual RAI road maps, including how to structure and implement governance, technology, and operating models. RAI frameworks can ensure that a telco\u0026rsquo;s AI deployments remain aligned with revenue and business goals.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eIndustry-standard RAI frameworks are rare\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTelcos can benefit from RAI in multiple ways: better business outcomes, competitive advantage, sustainable growth, increased customer trust, enhanced operational efficiency, stronger talent attraction, and, of course, financial gains. Forward-thinking telcos recognize that robust RAI governance serves as a set of \u0026ldquo;good brakes\u0026rdquo; that enable them to \u0026ldquo;drive faster\u0026rdquo; to harness the full potential of AI while mitigating risks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBased on our interviews with senior leaders at telcos worldwide, few are currently at the advanced stage of RAI deployment, with a majority still at the foundational or evolving stages. One of the biggest roadblocks to telcos deploying RAI is the lack of industry standards. Telcos want to deploy RAI, but there is no single agreed-upon framework to aid them in their journeys. Thus, instead of proactively adopting RAI, telcos are reactionary, adding piecemeal governance standards as new regulatory requirements emerge. This approach helps telcos avoid legal and financial repercussions but does not result in the type of cohesive and strategic RAI deployments necessary to fuel innovation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMany governments have proposed or passed legislation to ensure that AI deployments are fair, transparent, accountable, and secure (Table 1). International organizations have proposed global policies for RAI, but none of these policies have been adopted on a wide scale (Table 2). And none of these regulations or policies are specific to the telecom industry.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Table 1]]\n[[Table 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eWhile telecom industry associations are making progress on defining RAI standards, there are still barriers to achieving near-term success:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eLimited leadership from central organizations.\u003c/em\u003e Telecom industry associations and standard-setting bodies can show more leadership in advancing RAI practices. While some organizations actively promote RAI, few have developed comprehensive frameworks or provided clear guidance to their members. This gap hinders telcos from adopting best practices and achieving consistent standards of AI responsibility.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eLimited availability of RAI industry benchmarks.\u003c/em\u003e The absence of RAI benchmarks in the telecom industry creates a significant challenge for telcos. Benchmarks serve as reference points that allow companies to evaluate their performance relative to industry standards and identify areas for improvement. Without these benchmarks, telcos lack metrics to gauge their progress in implementing RAI. This gap complicates efforts to foster transparency, as key stakeholders\u0026mdash;including regulators, consumers, and partners\u0026mdash;have no clear standards against which to measure a telco\u0026rsquo;s AI initiatives.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eRAI frameworks for telcos have four characteristics\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDespite a lack of clear standards for their industry, telcos have a strong desire to implement RAI. In our interviews , the majority of leaders expressed interest in creating and deploying RAI frameworks tailored not just to the telecom industry but to their individual businesses. Most hoped to begin their RAI journey with maturity models that assess where they stand and define the specific steps needed to become advanced users of RAI. Telcos see maturity models as a level-setting exercise to inform their strategic plans. They want to deploy easy-to-use modeling tools to score their levels of RAI readiness and translate these findings into executive-level summaries with calls to action. Unfortunately, few of the leaders we interviewed said they currently use RAI maturity models, mostly because of the tools\u0026rsquo; limited availability. Telecom industry groups are working to define RAI maturity models specific to telcos, but it is still early days. For example, the Global System for Mobile Communications Association (GSMA) only recently created a tool for telcos to measure their RAI maturity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhat specific characteristics should an RAI framework for telcos include? Based on our interviews, a strong RAI framework for the telecom industry might encompass four key characteristics:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eIndustry-specific maturity models.\u003c/em\u003e These tools help telcos assess their RAI readiness and define specific benchmarks for each level. The models consider telcos\u0026rsquo; unique goals and challenges with AI in light of a highly competitive market, interconnected networks, and extensive exposure to consumer data.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eClear RAI guidelines.\u003c/em\u003e These building blocks offer a comprehensive overview of the various elements that comprise an RAI strategy, including governance, risk management, data quality, and ethical guidelines.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eBest practices.\u003c/em\u003e These practical strategies show telcos how to implement RAI effectively, including proven practices that advanced telcos have already successfully adopted and measured.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eProgress metrics.\u003c/em\u003e These measurement guidelines outline practical steps telcos can follow to improve their RAI capabilities and progress through each stage of maturity: foundational, evolving, performing, and advanced.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eIndustry-specific maturity models for assessment and goal setting\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAn effective RAI framework should include an easy-to-use maturity-modeling tool to help telcos fully understand their baseline AI readiness and identify opportunities for growth and improvement. Maturity models help telcos capture their full AI potential at every stage of deployment.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOperators just starting on their RAI journey can use maturity models to establish and measure essential foundational requirements. These include adopting core RAI principles, defining key roles and responsibilities, and setting up initial governance structures. Foundational requirements also include establishing a code of ethics for AI, appointing a chief AI officer, and creating an AI governance board. Companies in this foundational stage of RAI adoption are mostly looking to enhance specific aspects of their operations, such as improving operational efficiency or automating routine tasks like customer service.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOn the other end of the spectrum are companies in the advanced stage of RAI deployment. These telcos use AI to create high-impact, customer-facing use cases and integrate AI deeply into their strategic decision-making processes. Examples include using AI to create personalized customer experiences, to analyze vast amounts of data for strategic insights, or to spur innovation in product development. Thus, maturity models should integrate benchmarks and best practices for advanced users, including sophisticated risk management frameworks, comprehensive governance models, and continuous monitoring and improvement processes. For companies at the advanced stage, maturity models may also include AI auditing processes to ensure transparency and accountability.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eClear RAI guidelines to define overall strategy\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAn effective RAI framework outlines every step of a telco\u0026rsquo;s AI strategy and long-term road map. It includes definitions for governance, risk management, data quality, and ethics, with strategic and operational best practices to advance these policies at each stage of RAI maturity. The following are the essential components of an RAI framework.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eStrategy.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e This defines the vision and principles for RAI governance in alignment with the organization\u0026rsquo;s values and strategic goals. Here is what a robust strategy should include:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eVision.\u003c/em\u003e A clear articulation of what RAI means for the organization and how it aligns with the company\u0026rsquo;s broader mission\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003ePrinciples.\u003c/em\u003e Foundational ethical guidelines that steer AI development and deployment, ensuring fairness, transparency, accountability, and inclusivity\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eAlignment.\u003c/em\u003e Guidelines to ensure that the RAI strategy is consistent with the organization\u0026rsquo;s strategic objectives\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eRegulations.\u003c/em\u003e Rules to ensure adherence to local and international standards to mitigate compliance risks\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eEnablers.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e These activate well-defined best practices that are integral to a comprehensive RAI road map. Key features include the following:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTools.\u003c/em\u003e An inventory of the responsible AI tools the organization will use for model validation, bias detection, and interpretability to ensure ethical AI development\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTraining.\u003c/em\u003e A plan for continuous education and training to help employees understand AI\u0026rsquo;s ethical implications and technical aspects\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eChange management.\u003c/em\u003e A structured approach the organization will use to transition individuals, teams, and organizations toward RAI practices\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eCommunication.\u003c/em\u003e Clear, cascading communication channels to ensure that everyone in the organization is aligned with the RAI strategy and principles\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eOperating model.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e This helps ensure that the right talent, governance structures, team composition, and processes are in place to allow companies to implement RAI across all business activities. Critical elements include the following:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTalent.\u003c/em\u003e The recruitment and development of professionals with the necessary skills in AI, ethics, and governance\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eGovernance.\u003c/em\u003e Robust governance structures that define roles, responsibilities, and decision-making processes related to RAI\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTeam structure.\u003c/em\u003e Formation of cross-functional teams that include data scientists, ethicists, legal experts, and business leaders\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eProcesses.\u003c/em\u003e Implementation of standardized RAI development, deployment, and monitoring procedures to ensure consistency and accountability\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eCulture.\u003c/em\u003e The creation of a culture of ethical awareness and responsibility regarding AI, which encourages employees to speak up about potential issues\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eRisk.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e This emphasizes the importance of proactively monitoring and mitigating risks associated with AI and involves the following:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eMeasurement.\u003c/em\u003e Development of metrics and KPIs to evaluate the performance and risks of AI systems\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eMonitoring.\u003c/em\u003e Continuous observation of AI models for signs of bias, errors, or other issues through techniques such as risk management and third-party solution auditing\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eReviews.\u003c/em\u003e Implementation of rigorous review-and-challenge processes such as \u0026ldquo;red teaming\u0026rdquo; (simulating attacks to identify vulnerabilities) and \u0026ldquo;war gaming\u0026rdquo; (stress testing models under hypothetical scenarios)\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eReporting.\u003c/em\u003e Regular documentation and communication to stakeholders to ensure transparency and to facilitate informed AI decision making\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eBest practices to deploy RAI in the telecom sector\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAn RAI framework for the telecom industry should provide specific best practices for each of the four key components described above. These best practices can help telcos apply general principles of RAI in a manner that acknowledges the industry\u0026rsquo;s unique challenges and opportunities, such as using AI for network optimization or customer churn prediction. A comprehensive RAI framework provides best practices for each maturity level\u0026mdash;foundational, evolving, performing, and advanced\u0026mdash;creating a road map that helps telcos advance from one level to the next.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhat follows are sample best practices telcos could adopt at the foundational level of RAI deployment, though a full framework would provide a greater number of best practices and tailor them more specifically to an individual telco\u0026rsquo;s situation:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eStrategy:\n    \u003cul\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eVision.\u003c/em\u003e Write a high-level statement articulating the organization\u0026rsquo;s commitment to RAI that is aligned with the broader mission and serves as a guiding light for all AI activities.\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003ePrinciples.\u003c/em\u003e Define early ethical principles that provide a clear framework for RAI, touching on fairness, transparency, accountability, and inclusivity.\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eAlignment.\u003c/em\u003e Develop a road map to incorporate AI principles into the organization\u0026rsquo;s overall business goals.\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eRegulations.\u003c/em\u003e Conduct initial research to understand the regulatory requirements at both the national and international levels.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003c/ul\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eEnablers:\n    \u003cul\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTools.\u003c/em\u003e Find and adopt a first set of RAI tools to help with model validation, bias detection, and interpretability.\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTraining.\u003c/em\u003e Conduct an initial training program to educate employees about AI\u0026rsquo;s ethical implications to build awareness of RAI practices across the organization.\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eChange management.\u003c/em\u003e Start basic processes to help the organization adapt to RAI, such as creating a simple road map to describe the transition process.\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eCommunication.\u003c/em\u003e Choose channels\u0026mdash;for example, a newsletter, blog, website, or social media platform\u0026mdash;to disseminate information to employees and external stakeholders about the company\u0026rsquo;s RAI principles.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003c/ul\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eOperating model:\n    \u003cul\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTalent.\u003c/em\u003e Create a plan to obtain the necessary talent to deploy RAI, including required new hires and plans for upskilling existing employees.\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eGovernance.\u003c/em\u003e Set up an initial governance structure that defines roles and responsibilities for key stakeholders and outlines basic procedures.\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTeam structure.\u003c/em\u003e Take a high-level inventory of existing employees\u0026mdash;including data scientists, developers, IT staff, legal experts, product managers, and business leaders\u0026mdash;who could potentially join a cross-functional team to support RAI initiatives.\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eProcesses.\u003c/em\u003e Research standardized procedures for AI development, deployment, and monitoring, and introduce an initial set of unified procedures.\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eCulture.\u003c/em\u003e Create an initial internal communications campaign to introduce the concept of RAI.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003c/ul\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eRisk:\n    \u003cul\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eMeasurement.\u003c/em\u003e Develop basic metrics and KPIs to evaluate the performance of early RAI systems and set up initial measurement frameworks.\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eMonitoring.\u003c/em\u003e Establish basic processes to continually observe AI models to detect signs of bias, errors, or other issues.\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eReview.\u003c/em\u003e Create initial review-and-challenge processes, including plans for red teaming and war gaming.\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eReporting.\u003c/em\u003e Set up reporting mechanisms to document and communicate RAI findings, including basic reports to keep stakeholders informed about the state of AI initiatives.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003c/ul\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eProgress metrics to evolve from a foundational to an advanced maturity level\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAn effective RAI framework should offer a structured pathway for telcos to improve their RAI maturity over time. At each maturity level, the framework should include specific progress metrics a telco needs to meet to advance to the next level.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor example, at the foundational level, one progress metric might be: \u0026ldquo;Share the company\u0026rsquo;s RAI vision with all employees through an internal communications campaign and test their knowledge of the program through a feedback mechanism.\u0026rdquo; At the evolving method, a metric might be: \u0026ldquo;Finish a multipart risk training program for the RAI cross-functional team.\u0026rdquo; And at the performing level, a metric might be: \u0026ldquo;Develop and launch an RAI innovation lab to foster continuous improvement and experimentation.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEach telco will have different goals for RAI deployment, so their progress metrics will differ based on the unique objectives defined in their initial road maps.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTelcos with structured RAI practices are not just leaders from an ethical standpoint; they also stand to generate billions of dollars in additional value. Investing in RAI may position today\u0026rsquo;s beleaguered telcos for a competitive edge in the next decade, providing a new avenue for them to compete alongside technology companies. By prioritizing RAI, telecom operators can capture the full potential of AI for their businesses and build trust with customers, leading to new innovations and new revenues. Emphasizing RAI can also help telecom companies attract and retain the best talent, fostering a culture of continuous improvement. Put simply, implementing AI responsibly makes good business
